, Having thus dwelt with some minuteness on the anticipations of Bacon’s teaching to be found in the works of his almost equally 1 illustrious namesake in the thirteenth century, l may pass more lightly over the intermediate period.

Passing over about two centuries, during which, it may be noticed, the precepts and example of Roget Bacon seem to have had little effect (for the schools were engaged with far different work), we come to that almost universal genius—painter, poet, sculptor, architect, mechanist, mathematician, Leonardo da Vinci (b. 1452, d. 1519)¹².
